articles.headline: Crazy Like a Box: Going Public Can Give Start-Ups Outsize Power
articles.snippet: The billion-dollar start-up Box may provide a lesson for unicorns like Lyft about how even a painful I.P.O. can blossom into a competitive advantage against rivals.
articles.abstract: The billion-dollar start-up Box may provide a lesson for unicorns like Lyft about how even a painful I.P.O. can blossom into a competitive advantage against rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2014, when the cloud storage company Box filed for an initial public offering, many on Wall Street looked at its numbers and laughed. Box’s revenues were soaring, but its losses were growing nearly as quickly. It was pouring vast sums into sales and marketing, it had less than a year of cash remaining, and executives did not anticipate making a profit for years.

articles.headline: San Bernardino Shooting Kills at Least 14; Two Suspects Are Dead
articles.snippet: The suspects, Syed Farook and Tashfeen Malik, were killed after a shooting at a social services center. Family members said the two were married.
articles.abstract: The suspects, Syed Farook and Tashfeen Malik, were killed after a shooting at a social services center. Family members said the two were married.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — A heavily armed man and woman terrorized this city on Wednesday, killing at least 14 people and wounding at least 17 at a social services center before leading the police on a manhunt culminating in a shootout that left the two suspects dead, the authorities said.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ian Lovett and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Witness in Insider Trading Inquiry Sentenced to 21 Days
articles.snippet: Richard Choo-Beng Lee was considered a key witness in building a case against SAC Capital, but the judge still gave him a prison sentence.
articles.abstract: Richard Choo-Beng Lee was considered a key witness in building a case against SAC Capital, but the judge still gave him a prison sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has broken with what has been standard practice in the government’s multiyear crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry by sentencing a major cooperating witness to spend time in federal prison as opposed to a probationary sentence.

articles.headline: Transformation at Yahoo Foiled by Marissa Mayer’s Inability to Bet the Farm
articles.snippet: Ms. Mayer was hired as chief executive to transform Yahoo from a dull web portal into something new and exciting. But instead of bold, her tenure has been mostly boring.
articles.abstract: Ms. Mayer was hired as chief executive to transform Yahoo from a dull web portal into something new and exciting. But instead of bold, her tenure has been mostly boring.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not a big surprise that Marissa Mayer has failed to resurrect Yahoo. When the celebrated Google executive took over the web’s most iconic basket case in 2012, the odds were stacked against her. Turning around any company is difficult; turning around a tech company is nearly unheard-of. There’s just one example everyone can think of — Apple — but that effort took nearly a decade to show results, and anyway, if your requirement for success is to be like Steve Jobs, good luck to you.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg’s Philanthropy Uses L.L.C. for More Control
articles.snippet: The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative founded by Mark Zuckerberg, and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, is structured as a limited liability company, which will give the couple more flexibility in their giving.
articles.abstract: The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative founded by Mark Zuckerberg, and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, is structured as a limited liability company, which will give the couple more flexibility in their giving.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, the organization that the Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, introduced this week, has three important letters at the end of its name: L.L.C.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Yahoo Struggles as an Afterthought to Advertisers
articles.snippet: Twenty years after its founding, Yahoo, which still has a billion people using its apps and websites, is an also-ran in many ad budgets.
articles.abstract: Twenty years after its founding, Yahoo, which still has a billion people using its apps and websites, is an also-ran in many ad budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the third quarter of 2012 — Marissa Mayer’s first three months as chief executive of Yahoo — the company had about $1.2 billion in revenue, most of it from advertising. Three years later, its revenue was still $1.2 billion.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: How Often Do Mass Shootings Occur? On Average, Every Day, Records Show
articles.snippet: Including the attack in San Bernardino, Calif., 462 people have died and 1,314 have been wounded this year in shootings that left four or more injured or dead.
articles.abstract: Including the attack in San Bernardino, Calif., 462 people have died and 1,314 have been wounded this year in shootings that left four or more injured or dead.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Sarah Cohen and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Couple Kept Tight Lid on Plans for San Bernardino Shooting
articles.snippet: The brother-in-law of Syed Rizwan Farook, who carried out the rampage with his wife, expressed sorrow for the victims and bafflement at what had driven the couple.
articles.abstract: The brother-in-law of Syed Rizwan Farook, who carried out the rampage with his wife, expressed sorrow for the victims and bafflement at what had driven the couple.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik met online and married two years ago, after he presented himself on a Muslim dating site as a devout young man who liked to fix cars and memorize the Quran. They registered at Target when Ms. Malik became pregnant, with a cheery newlyweds’ catalog of wishes: a car seat, diapers and safety swabs.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ian Lovett, Julie Turkewitz and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: San Bernardino Suspects Left Trail of Clues, but No Clear Motive
articles.snippet: Officials pointed to materials the suspects stockpiled, including explosives; their Middle East travels; and evidence of contacts with people with Islamist extremist views.
articles.abstract: Officials pointed to materials the suspects stockpiled, including explosives; their Middle East travels; and evidence of contacts with people with Islamist extremist views.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — The couple who the police say killed 14 people and left 21 wounded here had stockpiled thousands of rounds of ammunition and a dozen homemade pipe bombs in their home, officials said Thursday, a sign that they might have been planning further attacks.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina, Richard Pérez-Peña, Michael S. Schmidt and Laurie Goodstein
